questions.text: Pulmonary sequestration most commonly affects which portion of the lung?
questions.solution:
BRONCHOPULMONARY SEQUESTRATION:

  • Partial or complete separation of a portion of a lobe of the lung with a systemic arterial supply with no connection to the functional components of the tracheobronchial tree (bronchial atresia).
  • Developmental abnormalities rather than acquired lesions.

Key Takeaways:

  • Pulmonary sequestration most often affects the left lower lobe.
  • Intralobar: Left posterior lower lobe, symptomatic, no separate pleura.
  • Extralobar: Near diaphragm/mediastinum, asymptomatic, separate pleura.

questions.text: The Azzopardi effect is seen in which lung neoplasm?
questions.solution:
AZZOPARDI EFFECT: Basophilic staining of vascular walls due to encrustation by DNA from necrotic tumor cells.

Hematoxyphilic DNA crusting of the vessel walls.

It is typically seen in small cell carcinoma

Key Takeaways:

  • The Azzopardi effect refers to basophilic staining of vessel walls due to necrotic tumor DNA.
  • It is characteristic of small cell carcinoma.
  • Identified by hematoxyphilic DNA crusting in vessel walls.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents with dyspnea. Chest X-ray shows a reticular pattern involving the periphery of the lung and the lung bases. A CT scan demonstrates peripheral honeycombing. The image shown is characterized by temporal heterogeneity. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
USUAL INTERSTITIAL PNEUMONIA (UIP)

  • Breathlessness and cough with a relentlessly progressive evolution
  • Respiratory failure after 3-4 years.
  • Acute exacerbation - by sudden worsening of symptoms and more rapid progression of respiratory failure
  • Heritable predisposition or have underlying systemic connective tissue diseases, most commonly rheumatoid arthritis, scleroderma, and systemic lupus erythematosus.
  • Microscopically, UIP is a primarily interstitial fibrosing process.
    • Areas of fibrosis is most advanced in peripheral, subpleural lung
    • Smooth muscle hyperplasia.

NSIP (Non specific interstitial pneumonias): Can look radiologically similar to UIP, involving the periphery of the lung and the lung bases; however, the interstitial process is histologically uniform and lacks the temporal heterogeneity of UIP. (Choice A)

RBILD (Respiratory bronchiolitis-associated interstitial lung disease)/fibrosis is thought to be the same process as DIP, but the disease is patchy rather than diffuse, affecting mainly the peribronchiolar areas. (Choice B)

DAD (Diffuse alveolar damage) is most commonly the histological correlate to ARDS. Radiologically, both lung fields are opacified ("complete white-out") in DAD, and hyaline membranes are classically observed in the exudative phase. (Choice D)

Key Takeaways:

  1. Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP) is characterized by honeycombing and temporal heterogeneity on histology.
  2. Presents with progressive dyspnea, subpleural fibrosis, and peripheral lung involvement.
  3. Distinguished from NSIP by its heterogeneous fibrosis and from DAD by absence of diffuse lung opacification.

choices.text: It is a neoplasm of adolescents
Mitoses are usually prominent but necrosis is characteristically absent
Nuclei show the classic neuroendocrine (salt-and-pepper) chromatin
Tumor cells are uniformly positive for HMB-45

questions.text: This 1.0-cm well-circumscribed lung lesion was discovered incidentally in an asymptomatic patient. Which of the following is TRUE about this lesion?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the above case is Clear cell tumors (sugar tumors).

PEComa (PERIVASCULAR EPITHELIOID CELL TUMORS) - SUGAR TUMOR

  • Clear cell tumor
  • Analogous to PEComas arising in other nonpulmonary sites.
  • Neoplasms of adults, with a median age of 50 at the time of discovery
  • Incidental finding in an asymptomatic patient
  • Usually small (2.0 cm or less).
  • Mitoses and necrosis are absent.
  • The clear cytoplasm is related to the high glycogen content of the cells.
  • IHC:
    • Uniformly positive for HMB-45, S100, Cathepsin.
    • Focal and inconstant positivity for actin, neuron-specific enolase, and synaptophysin
  • Microscopically:
    • large cells with clear to eosinophilic granular cytoplasm crowded with glycogen granules
    • Nuclei may be small with dense chromatin or large with vesicular chromatin.
    • Some cells have a 'spidery' appearance
    • Fat is absent
    • Mitoses are not seen
    • Scanty intervening stroma
    • Thin-walled vessels may be prominent, as well as extracellular amorphous eosinophilic material (sometimes calcified).

Key Takeaways: Clear cell tumors (sugar tumors), a type of PEComa, are incidental findings in asymptomatic adults (~50 years). They are small (<2 cm), lack mitoses or necrosis, and have glycogen-rich clear cytoplasm with thin-walled vessels. Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for HMB-45, S100, and Cathepsin.

questions.text: Which of the following immunohistochemical profiles is consistent with the lung tumor shown in this image:
questions.solution:
LUNG ADENOCARCINOMA - Malignant epithelial tumor with glandular differentiation, mucin production, or pneumocyte marker expression

  • It is the most common cause of cancer death world-wide.
  • Strong association with tobacco smoking
  • Histologic patterns: Subtypes-
    • Lepidic
    • Acinar
    • Papillary (image shown above)
    • Micropapillary
    • Solid
  • Immunohistochemistry panel for lung tumors:

Key Takeaways:

  • Lung adenocarcinoma is the most common cause of cancer death globally, often linked to smoking.
  • Histologic subtypes: Lepidic, Acinar, Papillary, Micropapillary, Solid.
  • Immunohistochemistry profile for lung adenocarcinoma:
    • CK7+, CK20-, EMA+, TTF-1+.

questions.text: The alveolar spaces in desquamative interstitial pneumonia (see image) are filled with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP)

  • Large collections of MACROPHAGES in the airspaces of a current or former smoker.
  • The macrophages were originally thought to be desquamated pneumocytes-thus the misnomer "desquamative interstitial pneumonia".

MORPHOLOGY

  • Accumulation of a large number of macrophages with abundant cytoplasm containing dusty brown pigment (smoker's macrophages) in the airspaces.
  • Some of the macrophages contain lamellar bodies (composed of surfactant) within phagocytic vacuoles, presumably derived from necrotic type II pneumocytes.
  • Thickened alveolar septa by a sparse inflammatory infiltrate of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and occasional eosinophils.
  • The septa are lined by plump, cuboidal pneumocytes.
  • Interstitial fibrosis, when present, is mild.
  • Emphysema is often present.
  • More common in the fourth or fifth decade of life
  • M=F
  • Cigarette smokers
  • Presenting symptoms: dyspnea and dry cough over weeks or months, often associated with clubbing of digits.
  • Pulmonary function tests: usually show a mild restrictive abnormality and moderately decreased diffusing capacity.
  • An excellent response to steroid therapy and cessation of smoking, but occasionally patients progress to interstitial fibrosis.

Key Takeaways: Desquamative Interstitial Pneumonia (DIP):

  • Macrophages fill alveolar spaces, common in smokers.
  • Symptoms: Dyspnea, dry cough, clubbing, often in 4th-5th decade.
  • Good response to steroids and smoking cessation.

questions.text: An adult female complains of on & off fever and cough, night sweats and chest pain occasionally since last two to three months. She also feels unenergetic. Radiographic findings show alveolar or fibronodular infiltrations in upper lobe. The histomorphological findings are shown in the the given image below. The diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Blastomycosis

  • Blastomyces dermatitidis: Soil-inhabiting dimorphic fungus.
  • The pneumonia most often resolves spontaneously, but it may persist or progress to a chronic lesion.
  • Three clinical forms:
    • Pulmonary blastomycosis
    • Disseminated blastomycosis
    • Primary cutaneous form (rare) that results from direct inoculation of organisms into the skin. The pneumonia most often resolves spontaneously, but it may persist or progress to a chronic lesion.

MORPHOLOGY:

  • Suppurative granulomas, neutrophils.
  • In tissue, b. Dermatitidis is a round, 5- to 15-µm yeast cell that divides by broad-based budding.
  • It has a thick, double-contoured cell wall, and visible nuclei.
  • Involvement of the skin and larynx is associated with marked epithelial hyperplasia, which may be mistaken for squamous cell carcinoma.

Key Takeaways: Blastomycosis, caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis, is a fungal infection that often presents with pulmonary symptoms like fever, cough, night sweats, and chest pain. It can progress to chronic lesions with histological findings of round yeast cells (5-15 µm) with broad-based budding and suppurative granulomas. The infection may also involve the skin and larynx, potentially mimicking squamous cell carcinoma.

questions.text: All of the following statements are false about the lung tumor shown below, except?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the above case is squamous cell carcinoma of Lung.

  • The second most common form of lung carcinoma, accounting for a third of incident lung cancers in males (choice C), 20%-25% of lung cancers in females
  • Location: Centered in segmental bronchi (choice A - not peripheral location)
  • Not associated with smoking (choice B)
  • chest radiographs and CT scans: Hilar or perihilar masses
  • Signs of bronchial obstruction (obstructive pneumonia or atelectasis)
  • Gross - Central necrosis with cavitation. (The given gross image of lung)
  • If Squamous cell carcinomas are found peripherally/subpleurally, they fill the alveolar lumens in a lepidic-like fashion, mimics adenocarcinoma of lung. (Which gives favourable outcome)
  • Microscopically:
    • keratinization and/or intercellular bridges
    • Keratin formation may be seen in isolated cells or, 'keratin pearls'.
    • Isolated necrotic cells should not be confused with keratinized cells.
  • IHC: Strong, diffuse positive staining for markers of squamous differentiation CK5/6, p63/p40. (Choice D)

Key Takeaways: Squamous cell carcinoma of the lung is typically centrally located in the segmental bronchi and is strongly linked to smoking. It most commonly affects men and is characterized by keratinization, intercellular bridges, and possible necrosis with cavitation. Radiographically, it presents as hilar or perihilar masses. It is cytokeratin positive (CK5/6, p63/p40).

questions.text: A 62 years old nonsmoker male presents with dyspnea on exertion and a nonproductive cough. He was working as a shipbuilder for more than 20 years. The histomorphological findings of lung are shown below. To which of the following conditions is this patient got predisposed?
questions.solution:
• Asbestosis is caused by inhalation of asbestos fibers, characterized by yellow-brown, rod-shaped ferruginous bodies with clubbed ends that stain positively with Prussian blue. (Shown in the image)
  • Asbestosis results in a marked predisposition to malignant mesothelioma of the pleura or peritoneum. (Choice D)
  • Asbestos related diseases include:
    • Localized fibrous plaques
    • Pleural effusions, recurrent
    • Parenchymal interstitial fibrosis (asbestosis)
    • Lung carcinoma
    • Mesothelioma
    • Laryngeal, ovarian, and perhaps other extrapulmonary neoplasms, including colon carcinoma
    • Increased risks for systemic autoimmune diseases and cardiovascular disease also have been proposed
  • Peritoneal mesotheliomas are related to heavy asbestos exposure in 60% of male patients.

Key Takeaways: Asbestosis, caused by inhaling asbestos fibers, leads to lung fibrosis and is strongly linked to malignant mesothelioma of the pleura. It is characterized by ferruginous bodies (yellow-brown, rod-shaped with clubbed ends). Asbestos exposure also predisposes individuals to lung carcinoma, pleural effusions, and other cancers.

questions.text: All of the following are posterior mediastinal neoplasm, except?
questions.solution: Key Takeaways:

choices.text: In pneumocystis pneumonia, CD4+ counts less than 2000 cells/mm3
Mycobacterium avium - intracellular complex infections are seen with CD4+ counts < 1000 cells/mm3
Bacterial pneumonia in HIV infected persons are more severe than without HIV infection
All pulmonary infiltrates in HIV infected individuals are infectious in aetiology

questions.text: Choose the true statement from the following about pulmonary disease in Human immunodeficiency virus infection.
questions.solution:
• The implicated organisms: S. pneumoniae, S. aureus, H. influenzae, and gram-negative rods. Bacterial pneumonias in HIV infected persons are more common, more severe, and more often associated with bacteraemia than in those without HIV infection. (Choice C)
  • Not all pulmonary infiltrates in HIV-infected individuals are infectious in etiology. (Choice D) A host of non-infectious diseases, including Kaposi sarcoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and lung cancer, occur with increased frequency and must be excluded.
  • The CD4+ T-cell count determines the risk of infection with specific organisms. As a rule of thumb, bacterial and tubercular infections are more likely at higher CD4+ counts (>200 cells/mm3).
  • Pneumocystis pneumonia usually strikes at CD4+ counts less than 200 cells/mm3. (Choice A)
  • CMV, fungal, and Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare complex infections are uncommon until the disease is very advanced (CD4+ counts less than 50 cells/mm3). (Choice B)

Key Takeaways: Pneumocystis pneumonia typically occurs with CD4+ counts <200 cells/mm3, while Mycobacterium avium complex infections are more common with CD4+ counts <50 cells/mm3.

choices.text: Cystic fibrosis is an indication for lung transplantation
Bilateral lung transplantation has poor outcomes than single lung
EBV associated B cell lymphoma can occur post transplant
Morphological changes of chronic rejection correlate as bronchiolitis obliterans

questions.text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding lung transplantation?
questions.solution:
• The most common indications for lung transplantation:
    • End-stage COPD
    • Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
    • Cystic fibrosis (choice A)
    • Idiopathic/familial pulmonary arterial hypertension
  • Bilateral lung transplantation offers better survival as compared to single lung, (choice B) the latter may be performed to benefit two recipients from a single donor.
  • The transplanted lung is subject to two Major complications:
    1. Infection
      • In the early posttransplant period (the first few weeks), bacterial infections are most common.
      • CMV pneumonia occurs less frequently and is less severe.
      • P. Jiroveci pneumonia (rare)
      • Fungal infections - Aspergillus and Candida species
    2. Rejection.
      • Acute lung allograft rejection (several weeks to months after surgery) - Patients present with fever, dyspnea, cough, and radiologic infiltrates.
      • Chronic lung allograft rejection (3 to 5 years posttransplant) - cough, dyspnea, and an irreversible decrease in lung function due to pulmonary fibrosis.
  • MORPHOLOGY
    • Acute rejection: Inflammatory infiltrates (lymphocytes, plasma cells, and few neutrophils and eosinophils) around small vessels, in the submucosa of airways, or both. Diagnosis by transbronchial biopsy.
    • Chronic rejection: Bronchiolitis obliterans, (choice D) the partial or complete occlusion of small airways by fibrosis, with or without active inflammation. Bronchiolitis obliterans is patchy hence difficult to diagnose via transbronchial biopsy.
  • Infrequent complications: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)-associated B-cell lymphoma, (choice C) which most often arises within the lung allograft.
  • The overall median survival is 6 years, with younger patients and those undergoing bilateral lung transplantation having BETTER OUTCOMES.

Key Takeaways: Bilateral lung transplantation offers better survival outcomes than single lung transplantation. Common indications include cystic fibrosis, COPD, and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. Post-transplant complications include infections and rejection, with chronic rejection leading to bronchiolitis obliterans. EBV-associated B-cell lymphoma can occur post-transplant.

questions.text: Which of the following distant site is involved in more than half of the cases if lung adenocarcinoma?
questions.solution:
Distant spread of lung carcinoma occurs through both lymphatic and hematogenous pathways.

Lung tumors spread early throughout the body except for squamous cell carcinoma, which metastasizes late outside the thorax.

Metastasis may be the first manifestation of an underlying occult pulmonary lesion.

Distant metastasis:

ADRENAL GLANDS (more than half of the cases) > liver (30% to 50%) > brain (20% ) = bone (20%)

Key Takeaways: In lung adenocarcinoma, distant metastasis commonly occurs to the adrenal glands (in more than half of the cases), followed by the liver (30-50%), brain (20%), and bone (20%). Lung tumors typically spread early, except for squamous cell carcinoma, which metastasizes later.

questions.text: 39/M presented with sputum expectation and cough which contains gelatinous material since last eight months. He gets on and off fever, progressive dyspnea and cyanosis. Histomorphological findings of lung are given in the image below. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis of the above case is PROTEIN ALVEOLAR PROTEINOSIS (PAP)

  • Defect in pulmonary macrophage function due to deficient granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factor (GM-CSF) signaling, which results in the accumulation of surfactant in the intra-alveolar and bronchiolar spaces.
  • Radiological findings: By bilateral patchy asymmetric pulmonary opacifications.
  • Symptoms:
    • Cough, sputum containing gelatinous material
    • Progressive dyspnea, cyanosis
  • Marked increase in the size and weight of the lung.
  • 3 classes of PAP:
    1. Autoimmune (acquired)
    2. Congenital
    3. Secondary
  • Morphology:
    • Accumulation of intra-alveolar precipitates containing surfactant proteins, causing consolidation of large areas of the lungs with minimal inflammatory reaction (as shown in the image).
    • The alveolar precipitate is pink, homogeneous, and periodic acid-Schiff-positive and contains cholesterol clefts and surfactant proteins.

Key Takeaways: Protein alveolar proteinosis (PAP) is characterized by a defect in pulmonary macrophage function, leading to the accumulation of surfactant in the alveoli and bronchioles. Symptoms include cough with gel-like sputum, progressive dyspnea, and cyanosis. Radiologically, it shows bilateral patchy opacifications. The condition can be autoimmune, congenital, or secondary. Histologically, it features surfactant-rich precipitates in the alveoli with minimal inflammation.

choices.text: Localized bronchiectasis is seen in patients of cystic fibrosis
Most common organism found in the culture is Haemophilus influence
Bronchopleural fistula with empyema is a common complication
Diffuse bronchiectasis is associated with immotile cilia syndrome

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct abount bronchiectasis, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
BRONCHIECTASIS:

Permanent dilation of bronchi usually associated with destruction of some elements of the bronchial wall and inflammatory changes that extend into the surrounding or distal lung parenchyma.

  • Haemophilus influenzae is found in approximately half and Pseudomonas aeruginosa in 12% to 30% of sputum cultures from patients with bronchiectasis. (Choice B)
  • Bronchiectasis can be divided into localized and diffuse forms.

Localized bronchiectasis: Partial or total obliteration of the bronchial lumen by a neoplasm, foreign body, localized inflammatory process, inspissated mucus, or external compression (e.g. broncholithiasis due to a calcified lymph node)

  • Localized bronchiectasis is a common finding in patients with middle lobe syndrome.

Diffuse bronchiectasis: is a consequence of inflammation and postinflammatory destruction of airway walls that is usually the result of repeated episodes of infection.

  • Seen in patients with cystic fibrosis (choice A), Kartagener or immotile cilia syndrome (choice D) (primary ciliary dyskinesia), associated with complete situs inversus and infertility, and Young syndrome, associated with infertility caused by azoospermia

MORPHOLOGY: Inflammation of the bronchial wall is a constant finding in

  • In a more advanced stage, granulation tissue develops.
  • Distal lung parenchyma, shows a range of nonspecific postobstructive changes that may include organizing pneumonia.

Complications of bronchiectasis:

  • Bronchopleural fistula With empyema. (choice C)
  • Brain abscess, and amyloidosis are no longer frequent.

Key Takeaways: Bronchiectasis is a permanent dilation of the bronchi often caused by repeated infections. Haemophilus influenzae is the most common organism cultured. Localized bronchiectasis is typically due to external factors like a neoplasm or foreign body, not cystic fibrosis. Diffuse bronchiectasis is associated with conditions like cystic fibrosis and immotile cilia syndrome. Complications include bronchopleural fistula with empyema.
